title: Investigate function impact of replacing web3-provider-engine
body:
We should investigate the functional changes that will result from replacing `web3-provider-engine` with the extension's network client.


### Scope:
- "network methods", i.e. anything the network client tests cover

### Action plan:
- Discover differences by running network client tests against web3-provider-engine
- Document differences
- Decide what to do on a case-by-case basis
Hey team! Please [add your planning poker estimate](https://app.zenhub.com/workspaces/Core-621e46b4d7103800171d1b02/issues/MetaMask/core/1065?planning-poker) with Zenhub @Gudahtt @mcmire @xinnanyemm
Please [add your planning poker estimate](https://app.zenhub.com/workspaces/Core-621e46b4d7103800171d1b02/issues/MetaMask/core/1065?planning-poker) with Zenhub @cryptodev-2s
Only remaining item: the mobile difference list

## eth_chainId

#### Currently
 - On mobile, calls to eth_chainId are handled in RPCMethodMiddleware,  using the value from providerConfig
 - On extension, the network is not hit. When the provider type is infura, chainId is used from a constant. For custom providers, it uses the value from the providerConfig. For localhost, it would either be statically set to return 0x1337, or if you use _setProvider directly, it would be what ever chainId you passed in. 
 
 #### After web3-provider-engine removal
 - If the provider type is infura, chainId is used from a constant. If provider type is localhost or rpc, chainId will be the value in the provider config. If you use setProviderType with providerType localhost (which doesn't allow setting chainId), chainId will be `0x0`.
 - If the chainId in providerConfig is alphanumeric, but not valid hex, it will now throw.
 - in mobile, this method is overridden anyways.

## net_version

#### Currently
 - On mobile, calls to net_version use a static result if they are included in the list of 'allNetworks' (mainnet, ropsten, kovan, rinkeby, goerli). Otherwise, they will hit the network to resolve this.
 - On extension. when the providerType is infura, net_version uses a static result. When its a custom rpc, the network is hit to fetch the value.
 
 #### After web3-provider-engine removal
 - when the providerType is infura, net_version uses a static result. When its a custom rpc, the network is hit to fetch the value.
 - in mobile, this method is overridden anyways, but the same check will happen twice.

## BlockRef

#### Currently
 - on mobile, block tags ('latest', 'pending', etc) are left as is
 - on extension, they are re-written based on the value held by the blockTracker

#### After web3-provider-engine removal
 - blockrefs are re-written with the values from blockTracker.
 
 
## Sanitization Middleware

#### Currently
  - on mobile, requests who have transaction-like or filter-like params have `0x` prefixes added if they are missing. We assume that the value is already hex, though. In practice, only eth_call seems to hit this middleware, since all the other methods are handled by earlier middleware
   - on extension, no such behaviour exists.
   
#### After web3-provider-engine removal
 - network controller no longer handles this behaviour. If we want to preserve this functionality, we can merge https://github.com/MetaMask/metamask-mobile/pull/6079
 
 ## NonceTracker

#### Currently
 - on mobile, requests that impact the nonce for an address are updated and maintained inside of the noncetracker middleware. 
 - on extension, we use a package called [nonce-tracker](https://github.com/MetaMask/nonce-tracker) in the transaction controller.
 
 #### After web3-provider-engine removal
  - calls to getTransactionCount made to the provider are not handled by nonce-tracker.

@BelfordZ For the nonce tracker, does https://github.com/MetaMask/core/pull/1147 being merged now change anything going forward? i.e. you say after `web3-provider-engine` is removed, calls to getTransactionCount are no longer cached, but would that still be the case?

@mcmire yes, thank you for pointing that out. #1147 will resolve the difference as it pertains to the transaction controller. More broadly speaking, other calls to eth_getTransactionCount that might exist (or received through dapp api) still wont be cached, though. I will update with the above considerations.

edit: let me double check this...

getTransactionCount gets cached by [block cache middleware](https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L67) from [with a strategy of 'Block'](https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L67) - so it is cached, but not for long. web3-provider-engine actually uses the same block cache, so the behaviour doesnt change.

edit again: I think cache is the wrong word to use. I should say, handled by the nonce-tracker middleware inside web3-provider-engine/zero.

@mcmire upon further inspection, it seems we still need to update mobile to add some middleware that calls the transactionControllers nonce tracker when handling getTransactionCount, similar to how we do it in extension: 
 - [metmask-controller calls createMetamaskMiddleware](https://github.com/MetaMask/metamask-extension/blob/develop/app/scripts/metamask-controller.js#L1278)
  - [createMetamaskMiddleware handles eth_getTransactionCount](https://github.com/MetaMask/metamask-extension/blob/develop/app/scripts/lib/createMetamaskMiddleware.js#L38)
  
With just #1147 - the nonce tracker wont get used when the requests to the method eth_getTransactionCount are coming through the provider.
Makes sense @BelfordZ!

Regarding the `eth_getTransactionCount` method, I have a draft branch on mobile that should ensure that behaves the same as before. I've just left a comment here about it: https://github.com/MetaMask/mobile-planning/issues/798#issuecomment-1505919649
I can handle it as part of that issue

>If provider type is localhost or rpc, chainId will be the value in the provider config. If you use setProviderType with providerType localhost (which doesn't allow setting chainId), chainId will be 0x0.

>If the chainId in providerConfig is alphanumeric, but not valid hex, it will now throw.

Note that as of #1064, we have validation in place to ensure custom networks have a valid hex chain ID set. So this scenario should no longer be possible.

The situation with Localhost is weird though. That built-in localhost network isn't used by mobile, nor would it be useful for the extension. I'll make a note to remove that at some point.

Regarding block ref rewriting, note that only `latest` is rewritten to use the latest block number (on extension currently, and after replacing web3-provider-engine). `pending` and `earliest` and all other block tags are left as-is.

I believe that `encryption_public_key` and `eth_decryptMessage` are unaffected by the web3-provider-engine replacement. It shouldn't work today in the network controller because the implementation of that method relies upon encryption methods being passed into web3-provider-engine, but we don't pass them in.

I guess it might throw a different error now at least. But both before and after, it would throw an error.

There are a bunch more methods in the same situation (anything referenced here basically: https://github.com/MetaMask/web3-provider-engine/blob/cf612f898002833c36730d23972fe4c4dd483c76/subproviders/hooked-wallet.js#L700)

Edit: I believe the same would apply for `parity_postTransaction` and `parity_postSign`; they don't directly rely on any web3 provider engine parameters that are missing, but they rely upon `eth_sendTransaction` and `eth_sign`, which themselves would currently throw due to a lack of signing methods passed in.

It seems that these methods used to be intercepted by web3-provider-engine, but are now forwarded to the RPC endpoint:
- `net_listening`
- `web3_clientVersion`
- `eth_filter`/`eth_subscribe`-related methods

I am working on extracting this to a separate doc and consolidating the points you've made @Gudahtt. I will distill the information so that it is presented from the perspective of only the `core` repo and not other products.

I've updated the doc to incorporate all of the comments above. I also did another audit of the differences before and after replacement, and noticed a change in behavior with the `eth_signTypedData` methods. Take a gander at the doc and leave a comment if you see anything out of place.
@Gudahtt Are we good with this now?
Looks good so far but I'll take another look once #1116 is updated. I have been using that diff to ensure this document is complete.
@Gudahtt Ah fair. I have to run out for a bit here but I'll focus on fixing the conflicts on that PR when I get back. And then I'll get to the sanitization middleware PR 😅
I have reviewed the diff for #1116 again, and I believe this document is complete. Everything seems to be accounted for.
Marking this as done!
